subject: The Ising model
raw:
Spin interactions. <[silence]> Phase transitions. <[silence]> Lattice structures. <[silence]>

The Ising model, formulated by Wilhelm Lenz and his student Ernst Ising, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics. <[silence]> It consists of discrete variables called spins, which can take values of +1 or -1, representing magnetic dipole moments of atomic spins. <[silence]> These spins are arranged on a lattice, allowing interactions only between nearest neighbors. <[silence]> The model is used to understand phase transitions, particularly the spontaneous magnetization in ferromagnetic materials. <[silence]>

In two dimensions, the Ising model exhibits a phase transition at a critical temperature, where the system changes from a disordered to an ordered state. <[silence]> Lars Onsager provided an exact solution for the two-dimensional Ising model without an external magnetic field, revealing the nature of phase transitions. <[silence]> This solution demonstrated that the model could predict critical phenomena, such as the divergence of the correlation length and specific heat. <[silence]>

The Ising model is not only applicable to magnetic systems but also to other phenomena, such as binary alloys and lattice gases. <[silence]> It serves as a prototype for studying complex systems and has been extended to include more complex interactions and dimensions. <[silence]> The model's simplicity makes it a valuable tool for exploring theoretical concepts in statistical physics. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are the Potts model, percolation theory, and Monte Carlo simulations. <[silence]>
